1580538058_1GDtf6kkYiCtruw42QmAeaHG1HsrW.body:
Thanks for sharing these information!
IMO this is still inconclusive; could it be that it infected some hosts (might be non-human) with HIV-1 and acquired the new insertions?

> [testuser3](#comment_78_1GDtf6kkYiCtruw42QmAeaHG1HsrWFywkg): It is clearly designed, the possibility of acquired is too tiny.  Twitter @halliburton50

I agree that the possibility is very small, but this does not constitute a solid proof without an evidence linking it with bio-engineering activities. Virologists should definitely research more on this though.

I am much interested in this and more input is welcome.

> [aspidochelone](#comment_349_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): invaded 

I am no virologist or biologist, but AFAIK the DNA of HIV-1 *is* transcribed back to RNA (by host's own cells) when replicating. Maybe some mishap occurred during that stage and the RNA of HIV-1 got inserted into the coronavirus... but then, if what you have said is true, the coronavirus would still be detached from the cells, thus, intuitively speaking, whatever happened should had extremely low likelihood.

On the contrary, it would be relatively easy to bio-engineer such insertions; furthermore, some Chinese researchers have released SARS-CoV from their lab back then, so it is highly likely that it is man-made. Though, given that nature itself had accomplished the improbable countless times, we do need some piece of evidence from the researchers allegedly responsible for the supposed release.

1580721027_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
I would be against copyright and anti-plagiarism system if the profit factor is disregarded; that is, assuming that one does not plan to financially profit from his intellectual works. The evaluation of an intellectual work should not include the judgment of its authors, hence credits or acknowledgments are irrelevant or even detrimental for this purpose. Indeed, having a copyright system generally adds a considerable workload to content creators and hinders content creation.

Current copyright systems on music, videos, et cetera seem to be for profit though. It somehow works but I speculate there are better systems.

> [blurhy](#comment_344_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): I started IPZN project (i.e. next-gen zeronet) for anti-copyright since it's hard to do something in the real world, but it's definitely feasible in the cyber world [...]

Your project seems to be a ZeroNet-like GUI for IPFS, which should be appealing to existing ZeroNet users. What other new functionalities are you trying to accomplish with IPZN? Is it possible to systematically integrate IPFS within ZeroNet?

(This is getting off-topic honestly :P)

> [blurhy](#comment_346_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): IPFS has enough functionalities to replace ZeroNet, but it's very hard to use so few people understand this point.However IPZN is aimed for anti-censorship which means it should be more resistant and robust.So I thought of integrating various protocols including IPFS, Zeronet, BT etc. into IPZN. As you know, the situation in China is serious.Integrating IPFS into ZeroNet is not good a idea because ZeroNet, compared to IPFS, is redundant and outdated but can be useful to make IPZN more robust.I'd keep IPFS as the main protocol used by IPZN. [...]

Functionality-wise, IPFS and ZeroNet are inter-reducible (at least for the core functionalities), since one could distribute files in form of ZeroSites and vice versa. Their utilities depend on the number of users, thus if your assessment is that your effort could assimilate a great number of users for IPFS, then by all means try it.

> [fractalzoomer@kxoid.bit](#comment_13_1GhYmYygr9AwgLDix4ge5AAQiMa4voJGuC): take 

Technically crediting is still possible through authentication methods like signatures... however, it seems impossible to provide economic incentive to independent creators. I am thinking of protocols such as commitments; while trust systems for cryptocurrency are well-developed, I cannot think of a way for content creators to ensure that their product is "useful information" for consumers.

I am no expert in cryptography and protocols as for now, so please notify me where I am misinformed.

> [blurhy](#comment_348_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): The principle of distribution in communist society is “from each according to his ability”and “to each according to his needs”.

It makes sense for traditional commodities and can be realized when production cost tends to zero. The same should apply to intellectual works if one is to profit from them, since the marginal cost of producing copies of the same piece of classical information is extremely low. Therefore, in the sense of average profit, selling truly valuable information would be undesirable (there is huge incentive for individuals to share the information if they have positive externality, which is often the case), and "communism" is automatically achieved.

1585399613_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
For pornography (and other video content in general), it might be possible to create them in a way without interfering other people at all utilizing advanced technologies (such as GAN and its variants). In other words, simulate the reality in some extent. We need researchers to bring such technologies into light, and that requires us to respect sex workers and stop regarding voluntary pornography production as taboo. Unfortunately this obviously demands a lot from the government (mostly law enforcement). I have yet to look into the literature to remotely grasp an idea what could be done in this regard, but this is certainly unlike dealing with drugs. (I do not think drugs can be easily counterfeited with any technological advancements coming soon; additionally, consents are not required from drugs themselves to be smoked by anyone)

I do not believe there is a way that targets specific content in a sufficiently "well-behaved" decentralized network without compromising complete freedom or availability; given how changing one single bit could completely scramble the content upon encryption, once there is a method to take a particular content down, it could be abused against any other content. Hiding the content would also be futile if the demand is high enough.

> [pepepanela](#comment_3_1Ab3JF91st5kW9WUgKdAcCNZp2E1vYALtT): I don't see anything wrong in having "Nth Rooms" flourishing all over decentralized networks like this. There is no real crime on that, they're just bits of data moving around computers. Transmitting controversial content doesn't harm people at all,  no victims are affected.The only problem in this world is bad parenting, those real people harming  little children and then exploiting them. The solution is not allowing idiots to procreate and bringing children to this rotten world, those people that don't take any responsibility of their heinous acts.  [...]

The problem with "Nth rooms" and "Red rooms" is that they allegedly harmed other real persons during production. I agree that, without this part, they are indeed merely data between terminals. When the production actually involved other real persons, ethical issues go completely haywire, as some ethics theories would actually blame the oppression upon the victims themselves (perhaps something related to the term "idiot" and such in your post).

> [blurhy](#comment_376_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): It depends how many people and who are using the network mainly, so the such demand won't be a large portion

"Demand" here refers to the demand to pornography as a whole, since it is reasonable to assume that users would first search for an index of pornography that is already well-maintained and comprehensive. By the time of writing I have not conducted a survey in the literature about estimates of pornography demands; however, judging how Pornhub flourishes, pornography demands are far from negligible.

Currently the vast majority use the clearnet. For generic users, they turn to decentralized networks when they find their demands hard to fulfill in clearnet. If you actually want to regulate some type of contents, it might be more effective to simply bring them into the clearnet where censorship is actually possible, though laws need to be rewritten to decriminalize the contents themselves.

By the way, there should be complete freedom among any form of anime pornography (and any other anime contents), as long as drawing anime does not involve oppression (for example, rearranging other people's body parts so that they make a decent substitute for high-end drawing devices)

> [blurhy](#comment_378_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): For example, there're a lot of Chinese users on ZeroNet, that is not only because of the demand of porn, but anti-censorship. As the dweb develops, it has much more features, and decentralized github or what can be anthoer reason why we use it, not just for porn. The influence of dweb increases, and illegal/unethical things should be reconsidered [...]

There is no unethical information or data (unlike the actions behind their production or consumption), and, since the very purpose of decentralized network is to defeat censorship which is usually alongside law enforcement, it is not sensible to pursue legality there. Therefore, if anyone wishes to exercise censorship, surveillance or regulation on a type of content, it must first be driven to the clear net, and it is definitely possible. For example, tobacco poses serious public health concerns, yet its usage is generally not criminalized (at least in personal spaces), hence the market remains relatively tractable (I am not aware of any user who enters dark web to specifically purchase tobacco) and regulation is possible.
